title: Chapter 7 bankruptcy 2 years ago. If I reopen case to file a motion to avoid judgment lien on home, they look @ value now?then?
question: I wondering, if a case is reopened due to an abstract of judgment on a home that needs to be "avoided", will the judge or trustee look at today's value or the value it had when I filed my petition 2 years ago? how can I be sure? If they look at the old value, would I have to somehow prove that up? how? At the time I had 25k in equity which we exempted. Now I have 125k.
answers: Property acquired after the filing of the bankruptcy is not property of the bankruptcy estate, and the date for determining which value to use is the filing date of the original petition. However, you should definitely consult with an experienced local bankruptcy attorney in your area to factor in the effect of local rules and decisions in prior cases in your jurisdiction. You would, in the face of an objection to your motion to avoid lien, need to provide sufficient proof of what the value was at the time of filing, and that the equity in your home was less than the allowed homestead exemption in your jurisdiciton. It appears there has been a dramatic uptick in the real estate market in your area and this could generate a great deal of interest in the true value, which may or may not be the value you placed on the property in your original bankruptcy schedules. You are asking very specific legal questions that truly need the attention of a qualified bankruptcy attorney in your area. Please find an attorney you can place your confidence in to assist you. All the best!

The value of the home doesn't matter unless the value has gone up over the homestead exemption. A judgment lien for a credit card or other dis-chargeable debt is avoided through a motion with the court.

Before you re-open the bankruptcy case, hire an attorney to contact the lender or its law firm who filed the lien and see if they will remove it. I have had some law firms and lenders remove the lien at no expense. I have had others charge what it would cost to re-open the case and file the motion. Tell the lender that this will make the judge happy by keeping the docket clear.

This is common element of bankruptcy law practice - use value at time if filing. These motions to reopen and motion to avoid lien are not the simple-variety, however, and they must be filed separately in the Central District CA Bankruptcy Court per local rules. You would be wise to hire an experienced bankruptcy lawyer to represent you and you will have the assurance of knowing the work is being completed properly. Be prepared to dig up evidence of home value at time of filing BK, evidence of all liens and amounts and more.

Best of luck

As Michael points out, for all things related to value of an asset and bankruptcy, the value at the time the case was filed is the number used. As for whether the court will allow you to re-open a case for something that should have been done at the time, hard to say. You usually need a good faith reason. You should look at the Bankruptcy Rules of Procedure and your courts Local Rules of Procedure to see if they fix a hard deadline for such motions (off the top of my head, I don't recall, but I wouldn't be surprised if such motions were subject to some sort of cut off date).
My opinion would be to use the value as of the filing date since post-petition appreciation in value is not "property of the estate."
